awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Comprehensive Blockchain Transaction Monitoring for Illicit Funds and Actors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is that it will result in powerful technology for detecting illicit cryptocurrency accounts and funds in close to real time. The commercial and market impact of the technology will be substantial with its ability to trace illicit accounts and funds to a depth and breadth never before possible and to accomplish this in seconds to minutes, as compared to the long to indefinite time it would take conventional network tracing technology.  For society at large, the ability to uncover the most complex money laundering and fraud schemes will help cut the flow of funds to the worst actors using cryptocurrency: organized crime, narcotics dealers, child pornographers, human traffickers, terrorists, and rogue nations. With the platform created in this project, governments in conjunction with the private sector will have tools that can effectively address the sophistication of the criminal schemes.  This will in turn result in greater growth of the cryptocurrency-based economy as businesses and individuals gain greater confidence that they are dealing with legitimate entities that are not seeking to defraud them.

This SBIR Phase I project will bring to light the most sophisticated illicit schemes involving cryptocurrencies. In doing so, it will secure cryptocurrency systems and advance the fields of network analysis and visualization, which will be needed to understand the schemes. There are three major technical hurdles in the Phase I project. First, the proposed implementation and infrastructure for the network tracing algorithms need to be scaled up to trace the entire Bitcoin and Ethereum blockchains in real-time. Second, to be able to trace addresses to known illicit accounts, a sufficient number of these accounts need to be identified. The proposed project will develop software for cross referencing account addresses with both on-chain and clear and dark web activity to build the lists of known bad actor addresses.  Third, for customers to believe the results of the analysis, a network visualization tool to show the chains of custody linking a suspect account to a known illicit account must be created. Because the algorithms can detect the schemes involving thousands of fund transfers between accounts, visualizing the links in a clear manner presents unique challenges. The project will therefore also build the foundation for its novel visualization tool in Phase I.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR Phase I Project proposed a technology platform for detecting illicit cryptocurrency accounts and funds in close to real time. This platform was composed of three main technical hurdles: 1) Scaling up Heights Labs proprietary algorithms for full-scale network tracing, 2) attributing and clustering addresses across a variety of threat and otherwise illicit actors on the Bitcoin blockchain, and 3) visualizing the flow of funds between two arbitrary selected entities, typically either from illicit sources to legitimate destinations or vice versa. The technical hurdles are obvious, namely how to map the flow of funds from any entity to any other entity through the hundreds of millions of transactions and billions of outputs recorded in the Bitcoin blockchain.  Nevertheless, our solutions were highly successful despite being very challenging to design, architect, and engineer.

 

The Heights Labs blockchain intelligence platform ranks all indirect flows from every entity that our system has identified by amount, hop, and category of service, both illicit and legitimate. This allows for a real-time map of the entire bitcoin blockchain along with the indirect source and destination of funds for every transaction between pairs of entities. All a user at either a private sector financial services provider, or a public sector law enforcement agency needs to do is choose the target of their investigation by inputting a transaction, address, entity, or even service category into our system.  The system then triages all flows from the entire data set across any of these parameters of interest. This takes all the guesswork out of investigations since the system already mapped where the funds of a particular entity were received from and sent to.  That is, the map of all the flows in the entire blockchain is instantly searchable.  An investigator can therefore simply select any particular transaction of interest and immediately have that chain of custody listed and also graphed automatically along with all relevant intermediaries in our visualization tool. 

 

The best evidence of the success of our Phase I prototype system is that it has already resulted in new leads, subpoenas, and arrests across a variety of threat actors, including sanctioned entities, dark net marketplaces, and perpetrators of hacks and otherwise stolen funds. The existence of the new cryptocurrency platforms opens infinite possibilities in the neverending game of cat and mouse between bad actors and the partnership of law enforcement and the legitimate financial system, both of whom are incentivized to keep out the bad actors.  Heights Labs? mission to create the best tools for cryptocurrency investigators is already paying off, and we look forward with great anticipation to adding even more capabilities to our system, and thereby more investigative power to our customers, in Phase II and beyond.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/12/2023
Modified by: Daniel Goldsmith
